climbs.name: Where A Wolf Learns To Fly

content.description: Getting your hands up to the top jug is pretty easy, but getting your feet up is tricky. There's a nub of quartz that can be used for your left foot toe, and your right heel could be placed on a small outcrop on the arete. Good spotting is needed for this final set of moves.
content.location: It's the slab the west face of the boulder, just around the arete to the left of the crack and "I Lost My Charger" (V3-). Start with a right hand crimp and a left hand thumb press or a crimp if you can get that high. Your feet start on a ledge.

climbs.name: Never Mind, Sorry, I Found It

content.description: Start wherever is comfortable. Use this route as a warm-up. There are enough holds on the route to keep it interesting, including some solid jugs. You must keep your feet on the arete, it'll be tempting to use the crack on the right side of the route. It is a good for practicing dynos. The topout is very comfortable.
content.location: It is on the arete to the right side of the South Face.

content.protection: A pad is required, there are some rocks at the base. Spotter optional until high feet in sketchy top out
content.location: This ascends a slightly overhanging crack on the south face, the photo makes it look like a slab. Start with a sidepull with both hands and your left heel hook on a ledge by the arete. Your right foot has a nice hold at the base of the crack.

content.description: The arete on the north face of Wolf Rock has some nice sidepulls. Start on the sidepulls and smeared feet. Work your hands up arete, and use the cracks on the face for footholds. This is a good warm-up route.
content.location: On the backside of Wolf Rock, this usually has some moss in the spring time. Use a grill brush to scrape away the moss.

content.description: This is a collection of 3 large boulders and 4 routes in a shaded area.
